docinfo.docinfo:doc-heading: DIVISION 3 OTHER EXCEPTIONS TO THE HEARSAY RULE [ss 69–75]

heading.title: DIVISION 3 OTHER EXCEPTIONS TO THE HEARSAY RULE [ss 69–75]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: DIVISION 3 OTHER EXCEPTIONS TO THE HEARSAY RULE [ss 69–75]

leg:heading.title: OTHER EXCEPTIONS TO THE HEARSAY RULE [ss 69–75]

p.text: This section applies to a document that:
either:
is or forms part of the records belonging to or kept by a person, body or organisation in the course of, or for the purposes of, a business, or
at any time was or formed part of such a record, and
contains a previous representation made or recorded in the document in the course of, or for the purposes of, the business.
The hearsay rule does not apply to the document (so far as it contains the representation) if the representation was made:
by a person who had or might reasonably be supposed to have had personal knowledge of the asserted fact, or
on the basis of information directly or indirectly supplied by a person who had or might reasonably be supposed to have had personal knowledge of the asserted fact.
Subsection (2) does not apply if the representation:
was prepared or obtained for the purpose of conducting, or for or in contemplation of or in connection with, an Australian or overseas proceeding, or
was made in connection with an investigation relating or leading to a criminal proceeding.
If:
the occurrence of an event of a particular kind is in question, and
in the course of a business, a system has been followed of making and keeping a record of the occurrence of all events of that kind,
the hearsay rule does not apply to evidence that tends to prove that there is no record kept, in accordance with that system, of the occurrence of the event.

For the purposes of this section, a person is taken to have had personal knowledge of a fact if the person's knowledge of the fact was or might reasonably be supposed to have been based on what the person saw, heard or otherwise perceived (other than a previous representation made by a person about the fact).
Sections 48 , 49 , 50 , 146 , 147 and 150(1) are relevant to the mode of proof, and authentication, of business records.
Section 182 of the Commonwealth Act gives section 69 a wider application in relation to Commonwealth records.
ALRC 26 vol 1 paras 702–707, 708–709
ALRC 38 para 129
Legislation cited in [50,625.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 cl 6, s 69, s 69(2), 69(5), ss 76–79.
These terms are defined in the Dictionary: “business”, “document” “previous representation” and “representation”.
The circumstances in which a document is to be taken to have been made by a person are set out in cl 6 of Pt 2 of the Dictionary.

Previous representations only fall within the business records hearsay exception if they were made by a person who had personal knowledge, as defined in s 69(2) and 69(5) of the Act: Lithgow City Council v Jackson (2011) 281 ALR 223; 85 ALJR 1130; [2011] HCA 36; BC201107453 (statement in ambulance report not admissible as evidence of cause of accident). For the purposes of s 69 , a previous representation may include a representation of opinion: Ringrow Pty Ltd v BP Australia Ltd (2003) 130 FCR 569; [2003] FCA 933; BC200305022 ; Investmentsource Corp Pty Ltd v Knox Street Apartments Pty Ltd [2007] NSWSC 1128; BC200708776 ; Street v Luna Park Sydney Pty Ltd [2007] NSWSC 688; BC200705555 (cf where the proposition was questioned but not actually rejected).

But a statement of opinion in a business record is only admissible if it complies with the opinion rule provisions in ss 76–79 of the Act: Lithgow City Council v Jackson, above, at [18]–[21]; Land Enviro Corp Pty Ltd v HTT Huntley Heritage Pty Ltd [2012] NSWSC 177; BC201201276 at [108] (representation of opinion inadmissible when based on assumptions about the correctness or prior, inadmissible opinions).
Legislation cited in [50,625.15] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 s 171, s 58.

Any matters necessary to satisfy the court of the application of the section may be proved by the affidavit of a person who falls within s 171 . The court has power under s 58 to draw inferences about admissibility.

level.toc-caption: [50,625.20] So far as the document contains the representation

heading.title: So far as the document contains the representation

p.text: The fact that the document contains an admissible representation does not mean that the whole of the document is admissible. However, other parts of the document may be admitted in order to identify the circumstances in which the representation was made and to clarify any ambiguities that the admissible representation may contain: Re Marra Developments Ltd and the Companies Act [1979] 2 NSWLR 193 at 202. The section only excludes the application of the hearsay rule to the document "so far as it contains the representation" in question.
Legislation cited in [50,625.25] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 Pt 2.

There is an inclusive definition in Pt 2 of the Dictionary that illustrates the kinds of activities than can fall within the description of a “business” for the purposes of the Act. That definition is sufficiently wide to cover any systematic information gathering activity: Valoutin Pty Ltd v Furst (1998) 154 ALR 119; BC9801119 ; see also Re Marra Developments Pty Ltd and the Companies Act [1979] 2 NSWLR 193 ; Trade Practices Commission v TNT Management Pty Ltd (1984) 56 ALR 647 at 650 ; R v Rondo (2001) 126 A Crim R 562; [2001] NSWCCA 540; BC200108335 ; Lewis v Nortex Pty Ltd (in liq) [2002] NSWSC 1083; BC200207060 . As was the case under the previous legislation, operations engaged in by the Crown in the right of the Commonwealth fall within the definition of “business”: Re Riggs; Ex parte Cmr of Taxation (WA) (1986) 9 FCR 149; 17 ATR 366; so also do the activities of government departments generally: Marriage of B (1987) 91 FLR 105 ; see also Ritz Hotel Ltd v Charles of the Ritz Ltd (No 18) (1988) 14 NSWLR 116 at 120–21 . The term is not restricted to the business of a party to the proceedings: Atra v Farmers and Graziers Co-op Co Ltd (1986) 5 NSWLR 281 at 286 per Wood J.
Legislation cited in [50,625.30] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 s 69.

The section is designed to render admissible proper records used in the everyday conduct of a business where they are made by persons whose interest is simply to record accurately matters relating to the business. The section is legislative recognition of the probable accuracy of business records and of the fact that they are likely to be more reliable than mere memory. Ordinary accounting records are plainly included within the concept of business records: (R v Mitchell [1971] VR 46 (bank ledger cards); R v Jenkins [1970] Tas SR 13 (bank statements); Re Action Waste Collections Pty Ltd (in liq); Crawford v O'Brien [1981] VR 691 at 701; (1981) 38 ALR 199 (books of account and bank statements). But the concept of "business records" extends well beyond accounting records. It has been held to include:
company reports, records of conversations between company officers and inter-office correspondence: Re Marra Developments Ltd and the Companies Act [1979] 2 NSWLR 193 at 197;
hospital records: R v Perry (No 3) (1981) 28 SASR 112 at 116 ; Albrighton v Royal Prince Alfred Hospital [1980] 2 NSWLR 542 at 548 ; and medical reports: Abourad v Strachan [1983] ACLD 677;
business letters: Companfina Bank v ANZ Banking Group Ltd [1982] 1 NSWLR 409;
an employee's work diary may form part of the records of the business: Standard Chartered Bank of Australia v Antico (1993) 35 NSWLR 588 .

A distinction can be drawn between “records” of a business and other publications such as books, reports or flyers which may record details of the business carried on but which do not amount to “records” for the purposes of s 69 : Roach v Page (No 27) [2003] NSWSC 1046; BC200307983 (informational material on a web site did not constitute a record of the business); Roach v Page (No 15) [2003] NSWSC 939; BC200306114 ; National Telecoms Group Ltd v John Fairfax Publications Pty Ltd (No 1) [2011] NSWSC 455; BC201103471 (analysts’ and brokers’ reports concerning the plaintiff, relied upon by an expert witness called by the defendant, were not admissible as business records); McMahon v John Fairfax Publications Pty Ltd (No 4) [2012] NSWSC 216; BC201201444 (consideration of ATO annual reports as “business records” — undecided — inadmissible on other grounds).

Statements made in documents received from third parties in the course of carrying on a business are not business records of the recipient (because they were not made in the course of that business): Trade Practices Commission v TNT Management Pty Ltd (1984) 56 ALR 647 at 659–60 per Franki J. Equally the documents will not form part of the business records of the sender (because it has parted with possession of them): Karmot Auto Spares Pty Ltd v Dominelli Ford (Hurstville) Pty Ltd (1992) 35 FCR 560; (1992) ATPR 41-175; BC9203478 ; Trade Practices Commission v TNT Management Pty Ltd, above at 659.

level.toc-caption: [50,625.35] Made in the course of, or for the purposes of, the business

p.text: Legislation cited in [50,625.35] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1898 s 14CE.

heading.title: Made in the course of, or for the purposes of, the business

p.text: Legislation cited in [50,625.40] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 s 69.

It is not necessary for the purposes of s 69 of the Act that the actual identity of the maker of the document should be established: Ross McConnell Kitchen & Co Pty Ltd (in liq) v Ross (1985) 1 NSWLR 233; see also Albrighton v Royal Prince Alfred Hospital [1980] 2 NSWLR 542 at 570. However, s 69(2) does require that evidence of personal knowledge of the asserted fact. Where documents have been written on behalf of other persons, the evidence may be inadmissible because the element of requisite personal knowledge is lacking: see Assaf v Skalkos [1999] NSWSC 1329; BC9909145 ; cf Australian Securities and Investments Commission v Whitlam (No 2) (2002) 169 FLR 383 at 428; 42 ACSR 407; BC200203998 . However, the section does not require that the person who is said to have had the relevant personal knowledge have any particular relationship with the business which is involved: Penrith City Council v Penrith Waste Services Pty Ltd [1995] NSWLEC 176 ; Vitali v Stachnik [2001] NSWSC 303; BC200101803 .

level.toc-caption: [50,625.45] Business records and the application of the opinion rule

p.text: Legislation cited in [50,625.45] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 s 69.

heading.title: Business records and the application of the opinion rule

p.text: The weight of authority favours the conclusion that the opinion rule does apply to documents admitted as business records pursuant to s 69 : Hadid v Australis Media Ltd (SC (NSW) 28 October 1996, Sperling J unreported); Connex Group Australia Pty Ltd v Butt [2004] NSWSC 379; BC200402627 ; Jackson v Lithgow City Council [2010] NSWCA 136; BC201003932 ; Quick v Stoland Pty Ltd (1998) 87 FCR 371; 157 ALR 615; 29 ACSR 130; BC9804969 ; Enviro Energy Australia (in liq) [2010] NSWSC 1217; BC201007806 ; cf Australian Securities and Investments Commission v Rich (2005) 216 ALR 320; 191 FLR 385; [2005] NSWSC 417; BC200502844 .

level.toc-caption: [50,625.50] Statements made “in contemplation of” or “in connection with” proceedings

p.text: Legislation cited in [50,625.50] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 s 69(3)(a).

heading.title: Statements made “in contemplation of” or “in connection with” proceedings

p.text: The purpose of the exclusion created by s 69(3) is to prevent the admission of hearsay material which is self serving because it has possibly been prepared to assist the proof of something known, or at least apprehended to be, relevant to the outcome of identifiable legal proceedings: see Vitali v Stachnik [2001] NSWSC 303; BC200101803 at [12]; Lewis v Nortex Pty Ltd (in liq) [2002] NSWSC 1083; BC200207060 . The section applies to both criminal and civil proceedings: W & M Wood (Haulage) Ltd v Redpath [1967] 2 QB 520: see also the Dictionary definition of “Australian or overseas proceeding”. A coronial inquiry is a proceeding under s 69(3)(a) : BestCare Foods Ltd v Origin Energy LPG Ltd (formerly Boral Gas (NSW) Pty Ltd) [2010] NSWSC 1304; BC201008461 at [12] (statement by NSW Fire Investigations Officer including observations of damage in a factory fire); R v Registrar-General; Ex parte Lange [1950] VLR 45 at 51 .

Section 69(3) refers to the making or obtaining of representation which is contained in the record. It does not refer to the production of the record for the proceedings in which it is sought to be used as evidence: see R v Dudko (2002) 132 A Crim R 371; [2002] NSWCCA 336; BC200204739 .

In order to be “in contemplation” within the meaning of the section, proceedings must be regarded as likely or as reasonably probable: Jarman v Lambert [1951] 2 KB 937; Shephard v Shephard [1954] VLR 514 ; National Bank of NZ Ltd v Chapman [1975] 1 NZLR 480; Bowskill v Dawson [1954] 1 QB 288; cf Smith v Smith [1975] 1 NSWLR 725; (1975) 5 ALR 444; Robinson v Stern [1939] 2 KB 260 at 266; [1939] 2 All ER 683 ; Feltafield Pty Ltd v Heidelberg Graphic Equipment (1995) 56 FCR 481 at 484–85; BC9507653 . Accordingly, a document prepared in circumstances where, although the facts are known, legal proceedings were a “distant and unassessable possibility” is not a document prepared in contemplation of legal proceedings for the purposes of s 69(3): Waterwell Shipping Inc v HIH Casualty and General Insurance Co Ltd (SC(NSW), Giles CJ, 50084 of 1996, 8 September 1997, unreported, BC9704168). Similarly, statements made to police after a caution or warning has been given have been held to be inadmissible: Robinson v Stern [1939] 2 KB 260; [1939] 2 All ER 683 ; Nachsatz v Prout [1959] VR 694 ; Hollington v F Hewthorne and Co Ltd [1943] 1 KB 587; [1943] 2 All ER 35. Documents that come into existence in contemplation of legal proceedings still fall within the hearsay rule even though they were not prepared for the dominant (or even a substantial) purpose of being used in connection with proceedings: Atra v Farmers and Graziers Co-op Co Ltd (1986) 5 NSWLR 281 at 290 per Wood J. BestCare Foods Ltd v Origin Energy LPG Ltd (formerly Boral Gas (NSW) Pty Ltd) [2010] NSWSC 1304; BC201008461 at [11] (statement by investigator about damage in a factory fire).

The term “in connection with” is generally used to convey an imprecise, but potentially wide, connotation. It clearly extends to statements that have a direct relationship with the present proceedings and includes, for example, a statement that was made in the course of a proceeding: Thomas v New South Wales [2008] NSWCA 316; BC200810500 at [7] per Hodgson JA and at [19]–[24] per Campbell JA (see also at [87]–[96] per Gyles AJA, dissenting). But it is also relevant to consider that the expression is used in the present section to limit the scope of the admissibility of “business records” that are otherwise an exception to the hearsay rule. It would be contrary to the general policy of the Evidence Act (to facilitate the admissibility of apparently reliable probative information) to adopt a broad interpretation of the “in connection with” expression and allow it to unnecessarily narrow the scope of the “business records” exceptions to the hearsay rule: Nye v New South Wales (2002) 134 A Crim R 245; [2002] NSWSC 1268; BC200208319 at [16] and following.
Legislation cited in [50,625.55] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 s 69(3)(a).

The words in subpara (e) of the definition of the term “Australian Court”, namely “a person or body authorised by an Australian law, or by consent of parties, to hear, receive and examine evidence” are words of wide meaning. The “proceeding” in a court is not confined to proceedings that involve the determination of a civil or criminal cause. A coroner is a person within the definition of subpara (e). A coronial enquiry is a proceeding under s 69(3)(a) : Best Care Foods Ltd v Origin Energy LPG Pty Ltd (formerly Boral Gas (NSW) Pty Ltd) [2010] NSWSC 1304; BC201008461 at [12] citing R v Registrar-General; Ex parte Lange [1950] VLR 45 at 51–52 .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [50,630] s 70 Exception: contents of tags, labels and writing

leg:heading.title: Exception: contents of tags, labels and writing

p.text: The hearsay rule does not apply to a tag or label attached to, or writing placed on, an object (including a document) if the tag or label or writing may reasonably be supposed to have been so attached or placed:
in the course of a business, and
for the purpose of describing or stating the identity, nature, ownership, destination, origin or weight of the object, or of the contents (if any) of the object.

The Commonwealth Act has an additional subsection. It provides that the exception does not apply to Customs and Excise prosecutions. Section 5 of the Commonwealth Act extends the application of that subsection to proceedings in all Australian courts.
ALRC 26 vol 1 para 712
ALRC 38 para 129
Legislation cited in [50,630.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 s 171, s 58.

Any matters necessary to satisfy the court of the application of the section may be proved by the affidavit of a person who falls within s 171 . The court has power under s 58 to draw inferences about admissibility.
Legislation cited in [50,630.15] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 s 70, s 70(b).

Although the section does not expressly apply to tickets, it is likely that they would be regarded as “objects” within s 70 . It is also likely that a name on the ticket would be regarded as having been written to state the ownership of the ticket for the purpose of s 70(b) . On this basis the section is consistent with R v Rice [1963] 1 QB 857 and overcomes the effect of the decisions such as Re Gardiner; Ex parte PRJ Gardner Pty Ltd (1967) 13 FLR 345 at 349 ; Patel v Comptroller of Customs [1966] AC 356; [1965] 3 All ER 593 and Comptroller of Customs v Western Lectric Co Ltd [1966] AC 367; [1965] 3 All ER 599 .
The hearsay rule does not apply to a representation contained in a document recording an electronic communication so far as the representation is a representation as to:
the identity of the person from whom or on whose behalf the communication was sent, or
the date on which or the time at which the communication was sent, or
the destination of the communication or the identity of the person to whom the communication was addressed.
Division 3 of Part 4.3 contains presumptions about electronic communications.
Section 182 of the Commonwealth Act gives section 71 of the Commonwealth Act a wider application in relation to Commonwealth records.
Electronic communication is defined in the Dictionary.
[s 71 subst Act No 46 of 2007 s 3 and Sch 1[30], effective 1 January 2009]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [50,640] s 72 Exception: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander traditional laws and customs

leg:heading.title: Exception: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander traditional laws and customs

p.text: The hearsay rule does not apply to evidence of a representation about the existence or non-existence, or the content, of the traditional laws and customs of an Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander group.
[s 72 subst Act No 46 of 2007 s 3 and Sch 1[31], effective 1 January 2009]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [50,645] s 73 Exception: reputation as to relationships and age

leg:heading.title: Exception: reputation as to relationships and age

p.text: The hearsay rule does not apply to evidence of reputation concerning:
whether a person was, at a particular time or at any time, a married person, or
whether a man and a woman cohabiting at a particular time were married to each other at that time, or
a person's age, or
family history or a family relationship.
In a criminal proceeding, subsection (1) does not apply to evidence adduced by a defendant unless:
it tends to contradict evidence of a kind referred to in subsection (1) that has been admitted, or
the defendant has given reasonable notice in writing to each other party of the defendant's intention to adduce the evidence.
In a criminal proceeding, subsection (1) does not apply to evidence adduced by the prosecutor unless it tends to contradict evidence of a kind referred to in subsection (1) that has been admitted.
Section 73(2)(b) is a notification provision for the purposes of Sch 2 Pt 2 cl 3(1) of the Evidence Act 1995, reproduced at [51,865] .

The section widens the scope of admissible evidence beyond that which would have been permitted by the common law in relation to pedigree declarations: Ceedive Pty Ltd v May BC200400229; [2004] NSWSC 33 ; but does not extend to permit evidence of detailed property transactions involving family members: Day v Couch BC200001309; [2000] NSWSC 230 .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [50,650] s 74 Exception: reputation of public or general rights

leg:heading.title: Exception: reputation of public or general rights

p.text: The hearsay rule does not apply to evidence of reputation concerning the existence, nature or extent of a public or general right.
In a criminal proceeding, subsection (1) does not apply to evidence adduced by the prosecutor unless it tends to contradict evidence of a kind referred to in subsection (1) that has been admitted.
ALRC 26 vol 1 para 710
ALRC 38 para 129

Public rights are enjoyed by the public generally. General rights are those enjoyed by the population in a specific locality. The distinction between the two is probably unimportant. Examples include rights of common: Evans v Merthyr Tydfil Urban District Council [1899] 12 East 62; [1899] 104 ER 25 (KB); customary manorial rights: Prichard v Powell (1845) 10 QB 589; 116 ER 224 (QB); and rights of corporations: See generally Davies v Morgan (1831) 1 Cr & J 587; 148 ER 557 (Ex).
In an interlocutory proceeding, the hearsay rule does not apply to evidence if the party who adduces it also adduces evidence of its source.
Legislation cited in [50,655.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 Rule 31.2.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 ss 13, 21, s 75.

Rule 31.2 requires evidence at interlocutory proceedings to be given on affidavit. See the notes to the rule at [31.2.10] . The section requires that the source of the hearsay evidence be given. Although there is no similar express requirement under the present section, the general provisions of the Act in relation to the manner in which evidence may be given (see for example, ss 13 and 21 ) require truthful evidence to be given.
The purpose of s 75 is to facilitate the conduct of interlocutory proceedings.

A proceeding for a permanent injunction is in the nature of proceedings for a final order and accordingly, is not an "interlocutory proceeding" for the purposes of s 75 : see Allstate Life Insurance Co v Australia & New Zealand Banking Group Ltd (No 3) (Allstate Judgment No 28) (1996) 64 FCR 55; 142 ALR 450; BC9602759 . The section implicitly assumes that there is no discretion to admit hearsay evidence on an interlocutory application: see Proctor and Gamble Pty Ltd v Medical Research Pty Ltd [2001] NSWSC 183; BC200101311 ; compare Geoffrey W Hill & Associates v King (1992) 27 NSWLR 228 . But this assumption must be read in the light of the nature of the issues that arise in the interlocutory proceedings: see [31.2.10] .

The section permits the admission of hearsay evidence if the source of that evidence is also provided. The purpose of this condition is to provide the court, and the opposing party with potential to contest and assess the evidence: Wily v Terra Cresta Business Solutions Pty Ltd [2006] NSWSC 949; BC200607320 . The section does not explicitly require that the stated source be a person with direct knowledge. But if “double hearsay” is relied upon, s 75 applies to both levels of hearsay and requires that the source of each level be identified: Liu v The Age Co [2010] NSWSC 1176; BC201007557 at [38]–[44]. Furthermore, there is support for the general proposition that proffered evidence is unlikely to justify any significant weight unless the stated source is a person who is reasonably likely to have knowledge of the relevant fact: New South Wales Crime Commission v Vu [2009] NSWCA 349; BC200909562 at [45] per Spigelman CJ.
